# Physician
As the primary care provider within the [color=#5b97bc]Medical[/color] department, Physicians are responsible for monitoring patients, ensuring they have the required medication, and operating on patients as necessary.
## The Body
A good understanding of how patients' bodies works is essential for saving lives and ensuring their visit to [color=#5b97bc]Medical[/color] has good outcomes.
[textlink="Learn more about The Body." link="OffbrandBody"]
## Topicals
Topicals are the first step in treating brute or burn injuries; every wound should be bandaged or salved before proceeding with treatment.
Each wound can only be bandaged or salved once; different medicated bandages and salves may be better for specific types of wounds.
[textlink="Learn more about Topicals." link="OffbrandTopicals"]
## Medications
After ensuring wounds have been treated with topicals, medications can be given to aid the body in healing, and to relieve pain.
[textlink="Learn more about Medications." link="OffbrandMedication"]
## Cryostasis
In emergency situations, you may not be able to attend to every patient in a timely manner.
Cryostasis devices allow you to slow down your patients' bodies, buying you more time.
[textlink="Learn more about Cryostasis." link="OffbrandCryostasis"]
## Surgery
Some patients may come in with internal injuries that surface-level administration of topicals or medicine cannot heal, invisible to your eye but reported by the health analyzer.
Ensure patients are stable and wounds have been treated before bringing them to an operating room.
[textlink="Learn more about Surgery." link="OffbrandSurgery"]
